title: These Hair Brushes Help Your Hair Grow in Faster and Thicker
description: It’s as simple as using them once or twice a day.

html:
Fan Favorite

Mason Pearson Handy All Boar Brush

I’d be remiss if I forgot to mention Mason Pearson brushes—mine is one of my most prized possessions, and I’m determined to make it an heirloom within my family. “While more expensive than most hair brushes, this iconic brush is composed of boar hair in an oval-shaped brush that is suitable for use on sensitive scalps and those with fine hair,” Dr. Camp explains. The brush is a pro at distributing the scalp’s natural oils down the hair shaft, stimulating blood flow in the scalp and strengthening your strands in the process.

Bristles: 100 percent boar hair

Neiman Marcus rating: 5/5 stars

A Neiman Marcus reviewer says: “At first, I had thought this brush would injure my scalp, but with continued use and not getting too heavy handed, I have found it to be excellent and perfect. The severe shedding has stopped, and my scalp feels great. Can’t say enough about this brush—surely worth the cost.”

Best with a Wooden Handle

Altesse Studio Beauté Classic Repair & Shine Brush

Pros
  • Comes with its own case and a built-in mirror

Made with olive wood and carefully selected boar bristles, this may be the most beautiful brush I’ve ever seen. When you hold it in your hand, you can tell that it was designed and constructed with great care. It’s something I love seeing on my vanity and incorporating into my beauty rituals. But it’s not just a pretty product—when used properly to massage the scalp, it encourages hair retention and new growth. In fact, in a four-week clinical study, 85 percent of participants noticed a visible reduction in hair loss and breakage.

Bristles: 100 percent boar hair

Bloomingdale’s rating: 4.8/5 stars

A Bloomingdale’s reviewer says: “As someone with hair that gets greasy the same day I wash it, I approve of this brush! I followed the instructions of 25 brushes per day forward, sideways, and backward, which yielded amazing results. The boar bristles are effective at evenly distributing hair oils throughout, and it also massages the scalp, which feels very relaxing. I have been able to go two to three days without washing my hair, which is a big deal for me. I must also say that this packaging and carrying case is so cute.”

Advertisement - Continue Reading Below

Best for Fine Hair

Crown Affair The Brush No. 003

Pros
  • Tames frizz and flyaways
Cons
  • Handle may feel a little short

No matter how quickly your hair grows out of your scalp, you won’t see the length increase if the ends keep breaking off. One of the culprits behind breakage could be a hair brush that’s too harsh or brushing too hard while your hair is wet and fragile. Using a gentle boar bristle brush like this one to detangle, break up buildup, and spread your skin’s natural oils (while your hair is dry, of course) is ideal when trying to grow out your hair.

Bristles: 100 percent boar hair

Crown Affair rating: 4.8/5 stars

A Crown Affair reviewer says: “I purchased my No. 003 brush two weeks ago, and don’t know how I lived without it. It seriously leaves my hair silky after the first brush, detangles my thin hair with minimal breakage, and almost completely gets rid of frizz. It’s crazy! Definitely worth the cost, and the quality is insanely good as well.”

Best Design

La Bonne Brosse N.01 The Universal Hair Care Brush

French-made brand La Bonne Brosse landed stateside just last year, and it’s already been getting lots of love from editors (including me). There’s just something about the playful yet luxe design of the handmade brushes that draws you in, and there are also a multitude of beautiful colors to choose from. The best part is that the more you use it, the shinier your hair will look, and you may even find yourself needing to shampoo less frequently, since your scalp won’t be so overloaded with sebum.

Bristles: 100 percent boar hair

The Detox Market rating: 5/5 stars

A The Detox Market reviewer says: “I look forward to brushing my hair! It feels great, and my stylist noticed a difference without me saying a thing. She said my hair looked incredibly healthy and shiny.”

Advertisement - Continue Reading Below

Best Vegan Alternative

Dae Vegan Detangle + Style Brush

Pros
  • Compact and travel-friendly
  • Has a combination of longer and shorter bristles
Cons
  • May feel a little small for some

If you don’t like the idea of using an actual boar bristle brush, Dr. Camp recommends this one as an alternative. “Made with vegan boar-like bristles, this styling and detangling brush can be used on dry and wet hair,” he says. The bristles are firm enough to encourage blood flow in the scalp yet gentle enough to avoid causing breakage or damage to even fine hair.

Bristles: 100 percent vegan materials

Dae rating: 4.7/5 stars

A Dae reviewer says: “I love this brush! I have previously used wet brushes that have regular bristles, but after using my sister-in-law’s boar bristle brush, I knew I needed to order this since it was a combo of both. I have hand-tied extensions that get matted easily, and this detangles it so easily. I do wish the brush was slightly larger, but it’s not that much of an issue. The other thing I’ve noticed is the minimal hair loss I have with this brush. After using it for two weeks, there is practically no buildup of my hair in the brush, so I think it is definitely helping me avoid damage and promote growth.”

Meet the Expert

Advertisement - Continue Reading Below

How often should you brush your hair?

Dr. Camp recommends brushing hair at least one to two times a day if possible. “This limits tangles and distributes oil or sebum throughout the hair shaft,” he says.

What are some other products and techniques you can use to encourage hair growth?

“Topical minoxidil is thought to help encourage hair growth by keeping hair in the growth phase of its life cycle for a longer period of time,” Dr. Camp says. He also says that scalp oils and serums can help by nourishing the scalp, while scalp massagers “may stimulate blood flow to encourage the delivery of oxygen and nutrients to hair follicles,” he adds.
